occurrences.line_text: But Trompart stoutly stayd to taken heed,
Vpon him lightly leaping without heed,
And of each turning still kept warie heed:
Or hast thou, Lord, of good mens cause no heed?
That ere she backe could turne to taken heed,
To all, that on him lookt without good heed,
And loe his hindparts, whereof heed I tooke,
So trauelling, he chaunst far off to heed
Did well auize, thenceforth with warie heed
Of that same Monster late, for lacke of heed,
Henceforth take heede of that thou now hast past,
And of our safetie good heede to take;
She there remain'd, but with right wary heede,
Through that same perillous foord with better heede,
For want of taking heede vnto the same,
So did she steale his heedelesse hart away,
But th'heedfull Boateman strongly forth did stretch
That had he not it shun'd with heedfull vew,
That had he not foreseene with heedfull vew,
That they the whiles may take lesse heedie keepe,
But by Gods grace, and her good heedinesse,
Was at his backe with heartlesse heedinesse,
How many mischieues should ensue his heedlesse hast.
For mine offence and heedlesse hardiment,
And whether art it were, or heedlesse hap,
That hasty wroth, and heedlesse hazardrie,
I read thee rash, and heedlesse of thy selfe,
How he their heedlesse harts with loue had fyred,
Pardon I pray my heedlesse ouersight,
Surcharg'd with wine, were heedlesse and ill hedded.
That with the shocke of their owne heedlesse might,
The headlesse tronke, as heedlesse of that stower,
Whose luring baytes oftimes doe heedlesse harts entyse.
But foolish Mayd, whyles heedlesse of the hooke,
Him heedlesse bit, the whiles he was thereof secure.
The whyles they strike at him with heedlesse might,
So bent his speare, and spurnd his horse with yron heele.
That from her shoulder to her heele downe raught,
Downe to her lowest heele, and thereuppon
And with his winged heeles did tread the wind,
And flew about his heeles in wanton wize,
And raught vnto her heeles; like sunny beames,
Still in a knot, vnto her heeles downe traced,
But with his heeles so sorely he him strake,
Feeling some curre behinde his heeles to bite,
Vnto his heeles himselfe he did betake,
He by the heeles him hung vpon a tree,
Inflam'd with wrath, his raging blade he heft,
And with such furie backe at him it heft,
And asked, to what end they clomb that tedious height.
That I was sonne and heire vnto a king,
And of my kingdome heire apparaunt bee:
The wofull daughter, and forsaken heire
Who dying left none heire them to withstand,
And Tristram is my name, the onely heire
So that for want of heires it to defend,
And all the world in their subiection held;
And in her hand she held a mirrhour bright,
And on his dagger still his hand he held,
So long in secret cabin there he held
That earst vs held in loue of lingring life;
She held him fast, and firmely did vpbeare,
And in her hand a sharpe bore-speare she held,
Those deadly tooles, which in her hand she held,
And deadly sharpe he held, whose heads were dight
Yielded by him, that held it forcibly.
And euer held his hand vpon his hart:
Disdeigning to be held so long in fight;
In his right hand an yron club he held,
She held a great gold chaine ylincked well,
Those that were low themselues, held others hard,
Held downe her head, the whiles her louely face
And things foregone through many ages held,
They held this land, and with their filthinesse
And all mens harts in dew obedience held:
Held on his course with stayed stedfastnesse,
In her left hand a Cup of gold she held,
So held them vnder fast, the whiles the rest
Which Vther with those forrein Pagans held,
Yet he perforce him held, and strokes vpon him hept.
So him he held, and did through might amate:
So long he held him, and him bet so long,
But answerd, Sir him wise I neuer held,
Sad Clotho held the rocke, the whiles the thrid
And in their hands their idle troncheons held,
He in an open Turney lately held,
He held the Lady forth before him right,
Yet held her wrathfull hand from vengeance sore,
Held vertue for it selfe in soueraine awe:
He her vnwares attacht, and captiue held by might.
And forth to bring those thrals, which there he held.
And him embracing fast betwixt them held,
The pledge of faith, her hand engaged held,
Though vertue then were held in highest price,
For his great iustice, held in high regard;
And had he not bene held, he nought had fayld of it.
That Damzell, whom he held as wrongfull prisonere.
And in his hand an huge long staffe he held,
But he then tooke it vp, and held fast in his hand.
His deadly weapon, which in hand he held.
The other held a snake with venime fraught,
In his right hand he held a trembling dart,
And in his left he held a sharpe borespeare,
And be for euer held a recreant Knight,
And held the same so hard, that by no wize
But streight he held his hand at his commaundement.
Laide heauy hands on him, and held so strayte,
Whom with his weight vnweldy downe he held,
Vow'd to the gods: religio[n] held euen theeues in measure.
She long so held, and softly weeping sayd;
His shield he on him threw, and fast downe held;
To be downe held, and maystred so with might,
And had of her, faire Helen for his meed,
Faire Helena, the fairest liuing wight;
Faire Helene, flowre of beautie excellent,
Here Sleep, there Richesse, & Hel-gate the[m] both betwext.
With th'Heliconian maides for maistery;
When those accursed messengers of hell,
And sad Proserpina the Queene of hell;
And vnto hell him selfe for money sold;
his cure to hell does goe.
Descends to hell: there creature neuer past,
For she in hell and heauen had power equally.
But vnto hell did thrust him downe aliue,
In deepest Hell, and framd by Furies skill,
But all a deepe descent, as darke as hell,
A man of hell, that cals himselfe Despaire:
As hell she hated, chast in worke and will;
Had past the paines of hell, and long enduring night.
And he that harrowd hell with heauie stowre,
When sin, and hell, and death do most dismay
Wide gaped, like the griesly mouth of hell,
That cursed man, that cruell feend of hell,
That to the gate of Hell, which gaped wide,
And lower part did reach to lowest Hell;
Whose hideous shapes were like to feends of hell,
That seem'd more horrible then hell to bee,
Was fled afore, affraid of him, as feend of hell.
And brutish shape thrust downe to hell below,
Chase her away, from whence she came, to hell.
So made him thinke him selfe in heauen, that was in hell.
As if he heauen and hell would ouerronne,
Dragons, and Minotaures, and feendes of hell,
Or paines in loue, or punishments in hell;
Hard by the gates of hell her dwelling is,
So many Centaures drunken soules to hell,
Firebrand of hell first tynd in Phlegeton,
For louers heauen must passe by sorrowes hell.
Both grace and gaine; but he in hell doth lie,
Was fled to hell, surcharg'd with spoile and theft.
And fire deuoure the ayre, and hell them quight,
Like to the balefull house of lowest hell,
And lowest hell, to which I lie most neare,
Then would he ballaunce heauen and hell together,
But some doe say, it goeth downe to hell.
And hell vnto him selfe with horrour great.
That swarmes of damned soules to hell he sends:
And greedy mouth, wide gaping like hell gate,
Of griesly theeues, she thought her self in hell,
Or other dyrefull hap from heauen or hell
Brought forth with him the dreadfull dog of hell,
Or like the hell-borne Hydra, which they faine
The hell-bred beast threw forth vnto the skyes,
By his deepe science, and hell-dreaded might,
Now like a Ram, faire Helle to peruart,
Phrixus and Helle from their stepdames feares,
Dead sleeping Poppy, and blacke Hellebore,
As Hellene, when she saw aloft appeare
This second Hellene, faire Dame Hellenore,
Malbecco he, and Hellenore she hight,
Vpon his lips hong faire Dame Hellenore,
Paridell rapeth Hellenore:
This second Hellene, faire Dame Hellenore,
And after asked him for Hellenore,
Faire Hellenore, with girlonds all bespred,
To see th'vnkindnesse of his Hellenore.
To Hellenore: so busses did abound.
And Hellenors both eyes did eke beguyle,
She poured forth out of her hellish sinke
Deluded so, gan threaten hellish paine
And by her hellish science raisd streightway
And coleblacke steedes yborne of hellish brood,
With stonie eyes; and all the hellish brood
And hellish anguish did his soule assaile,
The which doth quench the brond of hellish smart,
Which he from hellish entrailes did expire.
Her hellish brond hath kindled with despight,
But either hellish feends, or powres on hie:
And hellish fury all enragd, I sought
To rid a wretched man from hands of hellish wight.
With hellish feends, or Furies mad vprore,
What hellish furie hath at earst thee hent?
Outrageous wrong, and hellish couetize,
Of hellish Styx, which hidden vertue to it gaue.
But as a man, whom hellish feends haue frayd,
Or hellish feend raysd vp through diuelish science.
The hellish Harpies, prophets of sad destiny.
Foule horror, and eke hellish dreriment:
And hellish arts from people she might hide,
To fill his hellish gorge, it chaunst a knight
O Hatefull hellish Snake, what furie furst
For she at first was borne of hellish brood,
Wherewith the hellish fiends he doth confound.
Certes some hellish furie, or some feend
Of this accursed Carle of hellish kind;
That ere vnto his hellish den he raught,
He brought forth that old hag of hellish hew,
Horrible, hideous, and of hellish race,
She flew at him, like to an hellish feend,
Can remedy such hurts; such hurts are hellish paine.
For that same beast was bred of hellish strene,
That euen the hellish fiends affrighted bee
This hellish Dog, that hight the Blatant Beast;
Whylest thus she in these hellish dens remayned,
Vnto their hellish dens those theeues them brought;
Such was the fury of this hellish Beast,
It is a Monster bred of hellishe race,
That did the house of Richesse from hell-mouth diuide.
By which there sate a knight with helme vnlast,
And to them does the steddy helme apply,
And th'other brother gan his helme vnlace,
His Helme, to make vnto his vengeance way.
And shields did share, & mailes did rash, and helmes did hew.
Rashing off helmes, and ryuing plates a sonder,
They hew'd their helmes, and plates asunder brake,
And at his haughtie helmet making mark,
Therewith in haste his helmet gan vnlace,
But rudely rending vp his helmet, would
And shining helmet, soone him buckled to the field.
His haughtie helmet, horrid all with gold,
And pillow was my helmet faire displayd:
But thought his armes to leaue, and helmet to vnlace.
And glauncing on his helmet, made a large
On th'others helmet, which as Titan shone,
His shining Helmet he gan soone vnlace,
Vpon his head he wore an Helmet light,
Her Helmet, to her Courser mounting light:
Which faintly fluttring, scarce his helmet raught,
Which on his helmet martelled so hard,
Hath loosd her helmet from her lofty hed,
His haberieon, his helmet, and his speare;
With that her glistring helmet she vnlaced;
And doft his helmet, and vndid his mayle:
The wicked stroke vpon her helmet chaunst,
Vpon her helmet he againe her strooke,
And her sunshynie helmet soone vnlaced,
Thinking at once both head and helmet to haue raced.
Which when she saw, her helmet she vnlaste,
She her so rudely on the helmet smit,
She with one stroke both head and helmet cleft.
And on the helmet smote him formerlie,
His shield, his helmet, and his curats bare.
And helmets hewen deepe, shew marks of eithers might.
Were wont to riue steele plates, and helmets hew,
Hewing, and slashing shields, and helmets bright,
Ne helmets bright, ne hawberks strong did spare,
Speake, O deare Lady speake: help neuer comes too late.
And to my wound her gratious help impart.
Helpe then, O holy Virgin chiefe of nine,
O helpe thou my weake wit, and sharpen my dull tong.
For soueraine hope, which in his helpe he had:
God helpe the man so wrapt in Errours endlesse traine.
The last vaine helpe of womens great distresse,
Found neuer helpe, who neuer would his hurts impart.
If then it find not helpe, and breedes despaire.
O helpe Orgoglio, helpe, or else we perish all.
O helpe Orgoglio, helpe, or else we perish all.
Is not great grace to helpe him ouer past,
Of wretched soules, and helpe the helpelesse pore:
Gan faile, but by her helpe the top at last he wonne.
Witnesse ye heaue[n]s, whom she in vaine to helpe did call.
He oft finds present helpe, who does his griefe impart.
Hard helpe at need. So deare thee babe I bought,
And of him selfe great hope and helpe conceiu'd,
And giue you eke good helpe to their decay,
And beckned him, the last helpe she had left:
But he that last left helpe away did take,
But if she had her least helpe to thee lent,
Helpe, Ã´ Sir Guyon, helpe most noble knight,
Helpe, Ã´ Sir Guyon, helpe most noble knight,
Calling thy helpe in vaine, that here in ioyes art dround.
O Atin, helpe to me last death to giue.
And loudly cald, Helpe helpe, Ã´ Archimage;
And loudly cald, Helpe helpe, Ã´ Archimage;
Helpe with thy hand, or with thy counsell sage:
Yet sithens helpe, he saw, he needed more
Doth promise hope of helpe, and timely grace,
But by the helpe of Vortimere his sonne,
May often need the helpe of weaker hand;
But when she saw no helpe might him restore,
Then of my skill: who helpe may haue elsewhere,
O who shall helpe me to lament, and mourne
Or helpe himselfe, and laying thwart her horse,
And cride to heauen, from humane helpe exild.
And call aloud for helpe, ere helpe were past;
And call aloud for helpe, ere helpe were past;
That through the helpe of his faire hornes on hight,
That seem'd no helpe for him was left in liuing sight.
Perhaps this hand may helpe to ease your woe,
And squiers make hast to helpe their Lords fordonne.
In no lesse neede of helpe, then him he weend.
This hand may helpe, or succour ought supplie,
Through helpe (quoth she) of this old woman here
But if the heauens helpe to redresse her wrong,
At last to Tryphon she for helpe did hie,
Helpe therefore, O thou sacred imp of Ioue,
Helpe me to tell the names of all those floods,
All destitute of helpe doth headlong fall,
Her to haue swallow'd vp, did helpe to saue her.
But he that helpe from her against her will discarded.
And to his fortunes helpe make readie way?
And now for helpe aloud in earnest cride.
Crying for helpe aloud. But when as ny
Crying in vaine for helpe, when helpe was past.
Crying in vaine for helpe, when helpe was past.
With hope of helpe in that her greatest neede.
That it was she, the which for helpe did seeke.
Thereto great helpe dame Nature selfe doth lend:
For which the onely helpe now left them last
As if his cry did meane for helpe to call
That quite they seem'd past helpe of surgery,
For in your selfe your onely helpe doth lie,
What hope of helpe doth then for vs remaine,
To helpe faire Pastorella, home to driue
Her fleecie flocke; but Coridon most helpe did giue.
Gan cry to them aloud, to helpe ere all too late.
Would for the wretched infants helpe prouyde,
And being downe, ere he new helpe could call,
Bene helped through the swiftnesse of his steed,
Of wretched soules, and helpe the helpelesse pore:
Patience perforce; helpelesse what may it boot
But rather doth my helpelesse griefe augment.
To see an helpelesse euill, double griefe doth lend.
So miserably him all helpelesse slew,
Tho when all other helpes she saw to faile,
Seem'd to be Calidore: all other helpes were past.
Of forreine helpes to lifes due nourishment:
Then all their helpes they busily applyde,
Then they which sought at first their helping hand,
But his good Squire him helping vp with speed,
Whylest euerie one with helping hands did striue
And euery euening helping them to fold:
And helplesse hap it booteth not to mone.
Such helplesse harmes yts better hidden keepe,
They on this rock are rent, and sunck in helplesse wawes.
As gentle Ladies helplesse misery.
Thenceforth she sought for helps, to cloke her crime withall.
You to haue helpt I hold my selfe yet blest.
That her mis-shape much helpt; and her foule heare
Till aged Hely by dew heritage it gaynd.
Was hemd with golden fringe
Hemd in with waters like a wall in sight;
All clad in linnen robes with siluer hemd;
Hemd all about with fringe of siluer twine.
The whilest the rest them round about did hemme,
About his neck an hempen rope he weares,
Haling her palfrey by the hempen raines.
Was much asham'd, that with an hempen cord
From top of Hemus, by him heaped hye;
With bloud of Henalois, which therein fell.
In Henault, where yet of his victories
Far hence (quoth he) in wastfull wildernesse
But fly, ah fly far hence away, for feare
Shall vs restore, none else from hence may vs vnbynd.
Haue borne him hence to Plutoes balefull bowres.
Not far away (quoth he) he hence doth wonne
Certes (said he) hence shall I neuer rest,
The feeble soule departing hence away.
Is not from hence the way, that leadeth right
Let vs soone hence depart. They soone agree;
Like euer saw, but they from hence were sold;
Got from great Atlas daughters, hence began,
But let vs hence depart, whilest wether serues and wind.
Begin, ï¿½ Clio, and recount from hence
Hence farre away we will blindfolded lie,
Deliuer hence out of this dungeon strong,
But when she parted hence, she left her groome
That hence so long departed, is but vaine:
What mister wight (quoth he) and how far hence
Hence fare on foot, till he an horse haue gayned.
And where, and how far hence does she abide?
Playing on shaumes and trumpets, that from hence
And where is he thy Lord, and how far hence?
Doe serue a Queene, that not far hence doth wone,
Not farre from hence, vppon yond rocky hill,
And how ye may him hence, and to what part
Hence to professe: for shame is to adorne
That my ill fortune did them hence displace.
Spoyld all our cots, and caried vs from hence?
And henceforth euer wish, that like succeed it may.
Henceforth in safe assuraunce may ye rest,
Henceforth his ghost freed from repining strife,
And henceforth nothing faire, but her on earth they find.
Henceforth thy hated face for euer hyde,
Henceforth sir knight, take to you wonted strength,
Therefore henceforth be at your keeping well,
Or why should euer I henceforth desire,
Henceforth take heede of that thou now hast past,
And henceforth by this dayes ensample trow,
But him henceforth the same can saue no more;
Ne feareth he henceforth that foe of his,
Henceforth for euer Florimell to be.
But weete henceforth, that all that golden pray,
Henceforth faire Lady comfort to you take,
Henceforth may not disdaine, that womans hand
Ne henceforth be rebellious vnto loue,
And bid him eate, henceforth he oft shall hungry sit.
That from henceforth in batteilous array
That from henceforth he meanes no more to sew
Or reaue out of the hand, that did it hend.
To moue the world from off his stedfast henge,
Hengist and Horsus, well approu'd in warre,
And Hengist seeming sad, for that was donne,
And Hengist eke soone brought to shamefull death.
The little babe vp in his armes he hent;
And turning to that woman, fast her hent
What hellish furie hath at earst thee hent?
And his well proued weapons to him hent;
Great labour fondly hast thou hent in hand,
For losse of his deare loue by Neptune hent,
So forth he went, and soone them ouer hent,
But Talus by the backe the boaster hent,
For neither will one foot, till we that carle haue hent.
Who whilest in hand it gryping hard he hent,
First all the captiues, which they here had hent,
Yet he perforce him held, and strokes vpon him hept.
As time her taught, in lowly Shepheards weeds,
To blazon broad emongst her learned throng:
To winne him worship, and her grace to haue,
And heauie sat vpon her palfrey slow:
And by her in a line a milke white lambe she lad.
Behind her farre away a Dwarfe did lag,
Or wearied with bearing of her bag
Vertue giues her selfe light, through darkenesse for to wade.
Her huge long taile her den all ouerspred,
Her huge long taile her den all ouerspred,
Pointed with mortall sting. Of her there bred
Sucking vpon her poisonous dugs, each one
Into her mouth they crept, and suddain all were gone.
Their dam vpstart, out of her den effraide,
And rushed forth, hurling her hideous taile
About her cursed head, whose folds displaid
Where plaine none might her see, nor she see any plaine.
And with his trenchand blade her boldly kept
From turning backe, and forced her to stay:
And turning fierce, her speckled taile aduaunst,
Threatning her angry sting, him to dismay:
The stroke down fro[m]; her head vnto her shoulder glaunst.
The stroke down fro[m]; her head vnto her shoulder glaunst.
Much daunted with that dint, her sence was dazd,
Yet kindling rage, her selfe she gathered round,
And all attonce her beastly body raizd
Tho wrapping vp her wrethed sterne arownd,
Lept fierce vpon his shield, and her huge traine
Strangle her, else she sure will strangle thee.
Wherewith he grypt her gorge with so great paine,
That soone to loose her wicked bands did her constraine.
That soone to loose her wicked bands did her constraine.
Therewith she spewd out of her filthy maw
His grasping hold, and from her turne him backe:
Her vomit full of bookes and papers was,
Her filthy parbreake all the place defiled has.
She poured forth out of her hellish sinke
Her fruitfull cursed spawne of serpents small,
And strooke at her with more then manly force,
That from her body full of filthie sin
He raft her hatefull head without remorse;
A streame of cole black bloud forth gushed fro[m]; her corse.
Her scattred brood, soone as their Parent deare
Gathred themselues about her body round,
At her wide mouth: but being there withstood
They flocked all about her bleeding wound,
Making her death their life, and eke her hurt their good.
Making her death their life, and eke her hurt their good.
Of such as drunke her life, the which them nurst;
Whiles sad Night ouer him her ma[n]tle black doth spred
And fram'd of liquid ayre her tender partes
Her all in white he clad, and ouer it
And that new creature borne without her dew,
Her chast hart had subdewd, to learne Dame pleasures toy.
And she her selfe of beautie soueraigne Queene,
Her, whom he waking euermore did weene,
Whilst freshest Flora her with Yuie girlond crownd.
Vnder blake stole hyding her bayted hooke,
Most like that virgin true, which for her knight him took.
And halfe enraged at her shamelesse guise,
He thought haue slaine her in his fierce despight:
To proue his sense, and tempt her faigned truth.
Wringing her hands in wemens pitteous wise,
Both for her noble bloud, and for her tender youth.
Both for her noble bloud, and for her tender youth.
Her swollen hart her speach seemd to bereaue,
Her swollen hart her speach seemd to bereaue,
Her doubtfull words made that redoubted knight
Suspect her truth: yet since no' vntruth he knew,
Her fawning loue with foule disdainefull spight
Her mournefull plaintes, beguiled of her art,
Her mournefull plaintes, beguiled of her art,
So slyding softly forth, she turnd as to her ease.
Long after lay he musing at her mood,
